description:
It’s 19th-century Paris, and young vampire Noé hunts for the Book of Vanitas. Attacked by a vampire driven insane, a human intercedes, rescues Noé, and heals the sick creature. Commanding the book and calling himself Vanitas, this doctor tempts Noé with a mad crusade to “cure” the entire vampire race. Allying with one who wields arcane power so easily may be dangerous, but does he have a choice?

(Source: Funimation)
synonyms: บันทึกแวมไพร์วานิทัส

tags.name: Vampire
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a vampire.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

tags.name: Foreign
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a country outside the country of origin.

tags.name: Steampunk
tags.description: Prominently features technology and designs inspired by 19th-century industrial steam-powered machinery.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Anachronism
tags.description: Prominently features elements that are out of place in the historical period the work takes place in, particularly modern elements in a historical setting.

tags.name: Tsundere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who acts cold and hostile in order to mask warmer emotions.

tags.name: Historical
tags.description: Partly or completely set during a real period of world history.

tags.name: Gore
tags.description: Prominently features graphic bloodshed and violence.

tags.name: Chibi
tags.description: Features "super deformed" character designs with smaller, rounder proportions and a cute look.

tags.name: Tanned Skin
tags.description: Prominently features characters with tanned skin.

tags.name: Religion
tags.description: Centers on the belief that humanity is related to supernatural, transcendental, and spiritual elements.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Assassins
tags.description: Centers around characters who murder people as a profession.

tags.name: Surreal Comedy
tags.description: Prominently features comedic moments that defy casual reasoning, resulting in illogical events.

tags.name: Primarily Male Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of male characters.

tags.name: Henshin
tags.description: Prominently features character or costume transformations which often grant special abilities.

tags.name: Coming of Age
tags.description: Centers around a character's transition from childhood to adulthood.

tags.name: LGBTQ+ Themes
tags.description: Prominently features characters or themes associated with the LGBTQ+ community, such as sexuality or gender identity.

tags.name: Drugs
tags.description: Prominently features the usage of drugs such as opioids, stimulants, hallucinogens etc.

tags.name: Adoption
tags.description: Features a character who has been adopted by someone who is neither of their biological parents.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

name.native: アストルフォ・グラナトゥム

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/jun_mdesu)

A Japanese manga artist who began her professional career as a student. She is best known for the manga series _Pandora Hearts_ which ran in GFantasy from 2006 to 2015. She is also the author of the one-shot manga _Crimson-Shell_, running manga series _The Case Study of Vanitas (Vanitas no Carte)_, and illustrator of the _Boukyaku no Haou Roland_ and _Caucus Race_ novels.

Originating from [OLM](https://anilist.co/studio/28/), which he left to join [Shaft](https://anilist.co/studio/44/) in 2007.

In 2012, Itamura succeeded [Tatsuya Oishi](https://anilist.co/staff/103552/) as the director of the Monogatari series following Oishi's decision to adapt the Kizumonogatari novels as [movies](https://anilist.co/anime/9260/). Beginning with [Nisemonogatari](https://anilist.co/anime/11597/), Itamura directed all subsequent televised installments of the series under [Akiyuki Shinbou](https://anilist.co/staff/100089/)'s supervision, and after that left Shaft in 2017.

More recently Itamura has been seen working on [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/)' shows, with [Vanitas no Carte](https://anilist.co/anime/131646/) being his first directorial work there.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/yoshi_u)

Originating from [Tezuka Productions](https://anilist.co/studio/200/). Currently freelance, but often works for [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/).

Notable works as a character designer include [Fullmetal Alchemist](https://anilist.co/anime/121/), [Soul Eater](https://anilist.co/anime/3588/) and [Space Dandy](https://anilist.co/anime/20057/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/yoshi_u)

Originating from [Tezuka Productions](https://anilist.co/studio/200/). Currently freelance, but often works for [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/).

Notable works as a character designer include [Fullmetal Alchemist](https://anilist.co/anime/121/), [Soul Eater](https://anilist.co/anime/3588/) and [Space Dandy](https://anilist.co/anime/20057/).

[Website](http://hitodama.info/) | [Blog](https://ameblo.jp/hitodama1103/)

A Japanese singer, songwriter, radio personality and scriptwriter.

She has released 17 singles and 11 albums since her debut as a 13-year-old in 1994. Several of her songs have been used as anime theme songs. She is often mistaken for a voice actress because she is in the same field of activity as idol-esque voice actresses. When she is working as a screenwriter, she goes by the name Deko Akao, an alias made up from her senior [Satoru Akahori](https://anilist.co/staff/97460/)'s name.

Mother of a son and twin daughters.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E8%8B%A5%E6%9E%97%E5%92%8C%E5%BC%98)

**Kazuhiro Wakabayashi** is a Japanese sound director who was formerly affiliated with Techno Sound and Omnibus Promotion. After going freelance, he established his own sound production studio on May 7, 2004 called Fonishia. In 2013, he went freelance once again after his sound production studio disbanded.

**[SOUND BOX Profile (JP)](http://www.sound-box.jp/information/shizuo_k.html)** | **[SOUND BOX Profile (EN)](http://www.sound-box.jp/english/information/shizuo_k.html)**

Shizuo Kurahashi is a Japanese sound effects editor. He worked as an editor at the Nikkatsu filming studio. After that he started his sound career in ToyoOnkyo. 

He established his own company SOUND BOX in 1988. Since 1983, when the dolby stereo system got popular in Japan - he has been creating filmsounds. He has edited and arranged sounds for over 1000 works.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Fion0806) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100001583365922) | [Spotify](https://open.spotify.com/artist/0BLHMPWOZ2aTI0ZCCbtZem) | [Apple Music](https://music.apple.com/artist/yuki-kajiura/251013990) | [Deezer](https://www.deezer.com/artist/4663498)

Yuki Kajiura was born in Japan but raised in West Germany for most of her childhood. Her father was a big fan of classical and opera music and always desired for Yuki to play the piano for him. Yuki eventually gained a love for music and a love for the piano. Yuki started out as an SE programmer, but changed to music in 1992. She made her grand debut with a female trio called "[See-Saw](https://anilist.co/staff/104342)."  In the years to come the group released six singles and two albums. 

Yuki then went on to work on her solo career composing for artists and some TV, films, and games, such as _Blood: The Last Vampire_ in 2001, and _Xenosaga II_ and _III_. In 2001, Yuki's claim to fame came with the release of the anime [_NOIR_](https://anilist.co/anime/272). The soundtrack sold 50,000 copies. In 2002, she was brought on to project .hack to write the score to [_.hack//SIGN_](https://anilist.co/anime/48), along with vocalist [Chiaki Ishikawa](https://anilist.co/staff/101059) and New York singer [Emily Bindiger](https://anilist.co/staff/103845). Shortly after Yuki comprised an album of original and complied songs known as Fiction, working again with Emily Bindiger as well as _Xenosaga_ vocalist Deb Lyons.  

Yuki's other well-known works were for [_Mobile Suite Gundam Seed_](https://anilist.co/anime/93), which hit 5th on the Oricon Charts its first week, and selling over 200,000 copies. Yuki has also become known for her work on CLAMP's [_Tsubasa Chronicle_](https://anilist.co/anime/177) series, [movie](https://anilist.co/anime/807), and [OVAs](https://anilist.co/anime/2685). In 2003, she formed the project [FictionJunction](https://anilist.co/staff/103691) in which pairs Yuki's songwriting and composition with different performing vocalists, first as separate solo works and later into a singular group. In 2007, Yuki formed the band [Kalafina](https://anilist.co/staff/101975), with two partners from FictionJunction, Wakana Ootaki and [Keiko Kubota](https://anilist.co/staff/104664), to perform for the anime [_Kara no Kyoukai_](https://anilist.co/anime/2593), further working on several others. Kalafina disbanded in 2018, with their final lineup including Wakana, Keiko, and [Hikaru](https://anilist.co/staff/168857).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/lmykstaff) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/lmykmusic/) | [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCywnAZhXindfqW0vHhvvciQ/) |  [TikTok](https://www.tiktok.com/@lmykmusicofficial)  | [Old Website](https://www.lmyk.jp/) | [New Website](https://www.lisamonika-yk.com/) | [Old Spotify (LMYK)](https://open.spotify.com/intl-de/artist/7a2CrMd3xwcZDDC39OKUGg) | [New Spotify (Lisa Monika YK)](https://open.spotify.com/intl-de/artist/0Kk6nIkrAuKm2vQN3qVguF)

Japanese-German singer-songwriter.

Formerly known as only LMYK, Lisa Monika YK decided to share her name on [November 1st, 2024](https://www.lisamonika-yk.com/news/hellonovember) to mark a new chapter as an artist. The initials will still be LMYK, but she wants to connect more authentically by sharing her name.

[Website](http://hitodama.info/) | [Blog](https://ameblo.jp/hitodama1103/)

A Japanese singer, songwriter, radio personality and scriptwriter.

She has released 17 singles and 11 albums since her debut as a 13-year-old in 1994. Several of her songs have been used as anime theme songs. She is often mistaken for a voice actress because she is in the same field of activity as idol-esque voice actresses. When she is working as a screenwriter, she goes by the name Deko Akao, an alias made up from her senior [Satoru Akahori](https://anilist.co/staff/97460/)'s name.

In 2012, Itamura succeeded [Tatsuya Oishi](https://anilist.co/staff/103552/) as the director of the Monogatari series following Oishi's decision to adapt the Kizumonogatari novels as [movies](https://anilist.co/anime/9260/). Beginning with [Nisemonogatari](https://anilist.co/anime/11597/), Itamura directed all subsequent televised installments of the series under [Akiyuki Shinbou](https://anilist.co/staff/100089/)'s supervision, and after that left Shaft in 2017.
